channel.title: The correct way to use a switch statement in a private server environment

item.title: The correct way to use a switch statement in a private server environment
item.dc:creator: @Evil1 Evil_
item.description:
@Evil1 wrote:

In your efforts of trying to “contribute” to become a vet, you actually broke the rules. (Ironic, huh?)

[quote=“Taharok, post:1, topic:265742”]When Posting a New Tutorial
When you are posting a new tutorial, be sure that it covers all of the following:

[ul][li]It shows some effort put into it – it’s your work, show some pride![/li]
[li]It’s a tutorial relevant directly to RuneScape 2 Private Servers and nothing else.[/li]
[li]Any code snippets provided have been thoroughly explained with careful detail.[/li]
[li]Make sure that the work you post is only yours, unless you have permission to post someone else’s work and accredit them appropriately. Stealing work is not tolerated here.[/li]
[li]You may post a tutorial that has already been created if and only if it surpasses any existing tutorials of its type.[/li][/ul][/quote]

The main reasoning behind this rule, is because Sun (I guess Oracle now) already had a nice set of tutorials for Java.

Anyone wanting to learn about this, and many more things pertaining to Java, please visit: http://download.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/

Read full topic

item.title: The correct way to use a switch statement in a private server environment
item.dc:creator: @ranger_squad ranger squad
item.description:
@ranger_squad wrote:

Whilst there is not much difference on a small scale between if-else statements and switch statements (infact, it’s probably a lot easier to create an if-else statement if you only want to check an argument for one or two results), on a large scale, it is easier on both the user and the program if switch statements are used.

Anyway, on with the guide.

The first part of a switch statement is the specification, as this specifies which variable you will be searching through.

[code]int i;
public static void main(String args[]) {
switch(i) { //The specification

      }

}[/code]

Now, we must populate the switch statement with cases. Say that if the variable is 0, and we want to send them a message saying “I like zero”, we would do this:

case 0: //Which value will result in the action being performed. System.out.println("I like zero"); //Action break; //End of the case.
Now, if you forget to put “break;”, it will ignore everything in that action and continue to search for the next break, for example doing this:

case 0: System.out.println("I like zero"); case 1: System.out.println("i liek 1"); break;
If “i” was 0, it would instead print out “i liek 1”, so remember to put the breaks! (In some cases, not breaking the case can be useful, however.)

And that’s it!
If something hasn’t been fully explained, ask here!

To use this in a private server environment, you would do something like the following:

switch(ItemID) { case 1057: SendMessage("H'ween Mask!"); break; }

Read full topic
item.source: The correct way to use a switch statement in a private server environment
